original: HENNIG, Kurt Hugo, Ingenjör, Borås, f Borås 20/4 77 av grossh K H o Anna Liebold, gm Anna Bengtsson. Allm lärov. Tekn vävsk Borås, statsex v Högre Facksk f Textilindustri, Crefeld. Dessinatör v Mölnlycke Manuf AB 94—96, ord lär v Tekn vävsk Borås 98— 05, Skand repr f eng textilmaskinexp.fma 05 —10. Gr egen agentur o maskinfma Borås 10, ombild t AB Hugo Hennig m H som dess styr.ordf o vkst dir 19, då dta AB övertog den av H o hans svåger 07 gr första stålsolvfa-briken i Sverige. Led Linodl.ktén 18. Ordf Seråmatex (Sv Hdlsag Frns sektion för råvaror maskiner o förnödenhtr f textilind). Sekr Textilfrb Borås sed. 98. Resor: Besökt världsutst Paris 00, S :t Louis (USA) 04, Turin (Ital) 11, Gand (Belg) 12, Brux 28 mfl. Studieresor i Tyskl, Österr, Ung, Ital, Frankr, Belg, Holl, Engl, Irl, USA uppr ggr 97—40. Av trycket: Skand Tidskr f Textilindustri sed. 02. Inneh Sv Scoutfrbs Ht mfl utm.-tecken inom scoutrörelsen. Hobby: Författa fackupps o resebeskrivningar.
translated: HENNIG, Kurt Hugo, Engineer, Borås, born in Borås on 20/4 1877, son of wholesale merchant K. H. and Anna Liebold, married to Anna Bengtsson. General education at Tekniska vävskolan (Technical Weaving School) in Borås, state examination at Högre Fackskolan för Textilindustri (Higher Vocational School for Textile Industry) in Crefeld. Designer at Mölnlycke Manufaktur AB from 1894 to 1896, regular teacher at Tekniska vävskolan in Borås from 1898 to 1905, Scandinavia representative for an English textile machinery firm from 1905 to 1910. Established his own agency and machinery firm in Borås in 1910, which was later transformed into AB Hugo Hennig with himself as chairman and managing director from 1919, when this company took over the first steel wire weaving factory in Sweden, founded in 1907 by Hennig and his brother-in-law. Member of the Linoleum Board of Directors since 1918. Chairman of Seråmatex (Swedish Trading Association, Section for Raw Materials, Machinery, and Textile Supplies) and Secretary of the Textile Workers' Union in Borås since 1898. Travels: Visited world exhibitions in Paris in 1900, St. Louis (USA) in 1904, Turin (Italy) in 1911, Ghent (Belgium) in 1912, Brussels in 1928, and others. Study trips to Germany, Austria, Hungary, Italy, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, England, Ireland, and the USA on several occasions from 1897 to 1940. Published in Scandinavian Tidskrift för Textilindustri (Textile Industry Magazine) since 1902. Holds outstanding awards within the Scout movement. Hobby: Writing scientific papers and travel descriptions.
